title: Ticket #1106: 7.4.1 startd segfaults on Suse 10.0
description:

remarks:
2010-Feb-17 14:18:43 by psilord:
So far, I've found this SHA1 which is a problem on the V7_4_1-branch.

76691576580c4f0ea0663d70d9e00d7214c1a887 which is change [15224]

It is from ticket #551.

It would appear that the new function Jamie calls uses the param() system before init_params(1) is called a little later. This apparently causes some nasty problems in sysapi_reconfig() later, mostly because sysapi_reconfig() expected the param system to be fully set up.

The log snippet above states that the VM had an internal error and that would cause control to flow into the function Jamie used, which would cause param() to be called outside of its valid initialization state.

2010-Feb-17 14:41:23 by psilord:
Hrm, after a talk with Jamie, the first hypothesis might be a red herring. Moving on to more in-depth debugging.

2010-Feb-17 16:04:48 by psilord:
Tragically, the startd doesn't reproducably segfault with the initial claim of this ticket. I believe I can see how it can do this given the invalid write error, but I don't know if I can pin it down to be exact.

2010-Feb-25 11:50:34 by psilord:
This bug is proving elusive since it is a heisenbug. In my debugging, I'm seeing things which can cause it and tracking them down.

2010-Feb-25 14:35:39 by psilord:
The bug is looking like a double free, but valgrind somehow isn't helping me find it.

2010-Feb-25 15:20:25 by psilord:
The debugging command which reproduces the invalid reads/writes in the netowrk adapter code is: 

valgrind --tool=memcheck --free-fill=FF /usr/local/condor/sbin/condor_startd -f -t | & tee valgrind.log

2010-Feb-25 16:32:32 by psilord:
Ok, I (with dab's help) figured out the bug. Or more like, the lack thereof.

This bug existed on Nov 10, 2009, the date of the binaries I am debugging, but was fixed on Nov 30, 2009 for ticket #1011 in the 7.4 stable series. It took a while for me to realize this since I was looking at the head of the V7_4_1-branch as a reference (which didn't contain the implied bug) since I didn't have the snapshot of the source on Nov 10, 2009.

The answer is to produce a new build for this machine using the head of the 7.4.1 branch. This should fix the issue.

2010-Feb-26 10:50:10 by psilord:
New build of 7.4.1 is in:

nmi-0062:/home/psilord/git/CONDOR_SRC/public/v7.4/

That should hopefully solve this problem.

2010-Mar-05 13:38:45 by psilord:
Poked Nick, hopefully this should be installed soon.

2010-Mar-05 16:36:29 by psilord:
The new binaries woke up and are playing nicely with others. This ticket is resolved.
